two geared steam turbines - 1 shaft <ref Name=FAS/> |Ship speed={{convert|20|kn|km/h}} surfaced <ref Name=navysite/><br />{{convert|25|kn|km/h}} submerged <ref Name=navysite/> |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=Two crews of 13 officers and 130 enlisted <ref Name=navysite/> |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= • 4 × {{convert|21|in|mm|abbr=on}} torpedo tubes for [[Mark 48 torpedo]]es<ref Name=navysite/><br/>• 16 × vertical tubes for [[UGM-27 Polaris|Polaris]] or [[UGM-73 Poseidon|Poseidon]] ballistic missiles <ref Name=navysite/> |Ship notes= }} |} The '''''James Madison'' class''' of submarine was an evolutionary development from the {{sclass-|Lafayette|submarine|4}} of fleet [[ballistic missile submarine]]. They were identical to the ''Lafayette''s except for being designed to carry the [[Polaris A-3 missile]] instead of the earlier A-2. During the late 1970s and early 1980s, select units were further modified to carry [[Trident missile|Trident-I]] (C-4) missiles. This class, together with the {{sclass-|George Washington|submarine|5}}, {{sclass-|Ethan Allen|submarine|5}}, {{sclass-|Lafayette|submarine|5}}, and {{sclass-|Benjamin Franklin|submarine|5}} classes, comprised the "[[41 for Freedom]]." == Class Improvements == Improvements in the James Madison class included the [[ballistic missile]], [[missile guidance|guidance]], [[Fire-control system|fire control]], [[Inertial navigation system|navigation]], and launcher systems. The improved missile system introduced was the Polaris A3 missile. The A3 was restricted by size because it had to fit into the existing submarine launch tube. But it was {{convert|1.5|in|cm}} longer, weighed {{convert|4000|lbs|kg}} more, and had a range {{convert|1000|nmi|km}} farther than the A2. Additionally, the number of reentry systems was increased from 1 to 3, making this the first [[multiple reentry vehicle]] missile. The guidance, fire control, and navigation systems were improved to account for the longer range of the A3 missile.
